title: 113_hr2574
content: The "Keep Student Loans Affordable Act of 2013" extends the interest rate deadline to July 1, 2014. It also includes modifications to required distribution rules for pension plans. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to require distribution of an employee's interest within 5 years of their death for a trust to be qualified, with exceptions for eligible designated beneficiaries. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 requires distribution of an employee's interest within 5 years of their death for a trust to be qualified, with exceptions for eligible designated beneficiaries who can receive distributions over their life expectancy. If an eligible designated beneficiary receives distributions over their life expectancy, the portion of the interest will be treated as distributed on the date distributions begin, as per the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The portion referred to in subclause (E)(iii) is treated as distributed on the date distributions begin. For the surviving spouse of the employee, distributions must begin no earlier than when the employee would have turned 70 1/2. The surviving spouse must begin distributions no earlier than when the employee would have turned 70 1/2. If the surviving spouse dies before distributions begin, the rules apply as if the spouse were the employee. If an eligible designated beneficiary dies before their interest is fully distributed, the remaining portion is not subject to the same rules for any subsequent beneficiary. The definition of an eligible designated beneficiary is any individual designated as a beneficiary by the employee. If the interest of an employee's beneficiary is fully distributed, the remaining portion must be distributed within 5 years after the beneficiary's death. The term 'designated beneficiary' refers to an individual chosen by the employee. An 'eligible designated beneficiary' is a surviving spouse, a minor child, or a disabled individual at the time of the employee's death. The term 'eligible designated beneficiary' includes a surviving spouse, a minor child, a disabled individual, or a chronically ill individual. The term 'eligible designated beneficiary' includes a surviving spouse, a minor child, a disabled individual, or a chronically ill individual. An individual not more than 10 years younger than the employee may also qualify. A special rule applies to children who will cease to be eligible designated beneficiaries upon reaching majority age. An individual described in clause (ii)(II) will no longer be an eligible designated beneficiary upon reaching majority age. The distribution requirement must be met within 5 years after this date. Additionally, if an employee becomes a 5-percent owner after age 70 1/2, specific rules apply. The Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new clause regarding employees becoming 5-percent owners after age 70 1/2. The amendments apply to distributions for employees who die after December 31, 2013. The Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new clause regarding employees becoming 5-percent owners after age 70 1/2. The amendments apply to distributions for employees who die after December 31, 2013. Effective dates for the amendments are specified, including rules for employees becoming 5-percent owners before certain dates. Employees who have not retired before 2014 and meet certain criteria will be treated as 5-percent owners for plan years ending in 2013. Amendments apply to beneficiaries of employees who die after December 31, 2013. The amendments made by this section apply to beneficiaries of employees who die after December 31, 2013. Existing annuity contracts in effect before the enactment of this Act are exempt from these amendments. The section does not apply to existing qualified annuity contracts that were in effect before the enactment of this Act. A qualified annuity is defined as a commercial annuity or one payable by a defined benefit plan, with substantially equal periodic payments over the lives of the employee and a designated beneficiary. The section applies to qualified annuity contracts with substantially equal periodic payments over the lives of the employee and a designated beneficiary, meeting the requirements of section 401(a)(9) of the Code. The section applies to qualified annuity contracts with periodic payments over the lives of the employee and a designated beneficiary, meeting the requirements of section 401(a)(9) of the Code. An irrevocable election must be made by the employee before specific dates regarding the method and amount of annuity payments. The employee must make an irrevocable election before a specific date regarding the method and amount of annuity payments to themselves or designated beneficiaries.
